Splenomegaly is characteristically absent; if it is present, the diagnosis of aplastic anemia should be seriously questioned. Similarly, splenomegaly is also never seen in cases of ITP.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg. 1239, 1173

choices.text: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases
Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Transferrin receptor 1 iron responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Ferritin mRNA concentration iron responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the internal iron homeostasis in iron-deficiency anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis

 

In iron deficiency anemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis.

 

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases: This statement is incorrect. In iron deficiency, ferritin synthesis decreases as the body conserves iron, but the ferritin mRNA concentration does not increase.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis: This is incorrect because in iron deficiency, transferrin receptor 1 expression increases to maximize iron uptake.

 

Option D. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases: This is also incorrect. In iron deficiency, both ferritin mRNA levels and ferritin synthesis decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron-deficiency anemia, transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increase mRNA concentration and synthesis to enhance iron uptake, while ferritin levels decrease as the body attempts to conserve iron.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 1231-1234

choices.text: Environmental enteropathy
Celiac disease
Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW)

 

Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.

 

Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

 

 

  • Prior to biopsy, noninvasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features: -
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma

 

Treatment – Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.

 

DAPSONE for dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages (see image below).

 

 

Option D. Chronic pancreatitis: Causes malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Not associated with the specific histopathological features seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

choices.text: Transfusion reaction
Acute adrenal crisis
Fat embolism

questions.text: A 24-year-old man met with an road traffic accident and was brought to the casualty after 6 hours. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and Sp02 was 92%. A blood transfusion was done. After a few hours, the patient is febrile, tachypneic, and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels started falling. What could be the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transfusion reaction

 

Given the clinical scenario the most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction causing DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) resulting in bleeding from IV catheter and nasogastric tube within a few hours of blood transfusion.

 

Acute Hemolytic Transfusion reaction

 

  • Immune-mediated hemolysis
  • Preformed antibodies in recipient lyse donor erythrocytes.
  • Complement-mediated lysis occurs causing intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.
  • Severe cases, tissue factor released from the lysed erythrocytes may initiate DIC, which is a consumptive coagulopathy with bleeding manifestations.
  • Other complications include shock, acute kidney injury, and sometimes, death.

 

The various blood transfusion reactions according to their time of occurrence are as follows:

 

  • Anaphylactic reaction - Within a few seconds to minutes of the transfusion. Common in selective IgA deficiency patients.
  • Allergic/Urticarial reactions - Within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHT) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion


TRALI vs TACO:

 

 

TRALI: transfusion-related acute lung injury, TACO: Transfusion-associated cardiac overload, CXR: chest X-ray, BNP: B type natriuretic peptide, PAOP: pulmonary artery occluding pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute adrenal crisis: This condition involves sudden adrenal insufficiency, leading to hypotension, shock, and electrolyte imbalances. It would not typically cause the specific symptoms of hemolysis and DIC seen in this case.

 

Option C. Fat embolism: Fat embolism syndrome can occur after long bone fractures, presenting with respiratory distress, neurological symptoms, and petechiae. However, it typically occurs within 24-72 hours after injury and is not directly associated with blood transfusions.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from significant blood loss, leading to hypotension and tachycardia. While this could be a consideration, the transfusion reaction and subsequent DIC better explain the patient's clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), characterized by rapid onset of fever, bleeding from multiple sites, and hemolysis shortly after a blood transfusion.

questions.text:
A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has (11;14) positive. Which of the following markers should be done to confirm the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. CD10;
  2. CD 200;
  3. SOX11;
  4. Cyclin D1
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

t (11;14) creating CyclinD1-IgH fusion gene is seen in mantle cell lymphoma has its origin from naive B cell.

 

Mantle cell lymphoma:

 

  • Uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 8% of all NHL
  • Usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life
  • Male predominance
  • Tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers
  • More indolent, SOX11 variant that often presents with circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low Ki67 (<10%).

 

Features:

 

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon - lymphomatoid polyposis

 

Histology:

 

 

 

Immunophenotyping:

 

  1. High levels of cyclin D1
  2. CD19, CD20
  3. Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain)
  4. CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL.
  5. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Other Options:

 

  • CD10 (1): CD10 is a marker commonly associated with follicular lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not mantle cell lymphoma.
  • CD200 (2): CD200 is expressed in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and other B-cell lymphomas but is not a primary marker for mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with t(11;14) translocation, confirming the diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma requires testing for Cyclin D1 and SOX11 expression.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1132-1133

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.text: Which of the following are features of iron deficiency anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased

 

In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differential Diagnosis:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1231-1234

questions.text:
Which of the following are the classical markers of a seminoma: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. KIT    
  2. OCT 3
  3. PLAP
  4. HCG
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

The classical markers of a seminoma include KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (also known as OCT3/4), and PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase). These markers are commonly used in the diagnosis and characterization of seminomas due to their high specificity.

 

1. KIT (CD117): A receptor tyrosine kinase that is strongly expressed in seminomas, aiding in differentiation from other testicular neoplasms.

 

2. OCT 3 (OCT3/4): A transcription factor essential for maintaining the pluripotency of germ cells and expressed in seminomas, reflecting their embryonal origin.

 

3. PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): Frequently elevated in seminomas, this enzyme helps in confirming the germ cell origin of the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

4. HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): Although some seminomas may express low levels of HCG, it is not considered a classical marker like the others, being more indicative of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

HCG may be present in ~15–20% of seminomas. However it is a classical marker for Choriocarcinoma (produced by syncytiotrophoblastic cells)

 

Therefore, some seminomas can elevate serum hCG

 

However:

 

  • Not seen in all seminoma
  • More characteristic of choriocarcinoma and mixed germ cell tumors

 

Educational objective:

 

When diagnosing seminoma, clinicians should primarily focus on markers KIT, OCT3/4, and PLAP due to their high specificity and relevance to the germ cell lineage. HCG, although sometimes present, is not a classical marker for seminoma.

questions.text: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

Based on the patient's HbA2 and HbF levels, this patient likely has beta thalassemia major, a condition where the body produces less than normal amounts of hemoglobin beta chains. This results in a decrease in HbA, and an increase in HbF and HbA2.

 

Beta thalassemia will have high HbA2 levels (>3.5%) and slightly increased HbF

 

The peripheral blood smear of a patient with beta thalassemia major will show hypochromic microcytic red blood cells (Image 1), which are smaller and paler than normal. Howell-jolly bodies (image 2) will also be seen. These cells may also be more variable in size and shape, and may have a target cell appearance (Image 3) due to increased membrane-to-cytoplasm ratio.

 

Other possible findings on the blood smear may include anisocytosis (variation in cell size), poikilocytosis (variation in cell shape), and nucleated red blood cells (if the patient has severe anemia).

 

It's important to note that the blood smear alone is not sufficient to diagnose beta thalassemia major, and additional laboratory tests and genetic testing may be necessary for confirmation.

 

Image 2 shows Howell–Jolly bodies, which are small, round, dark purple inclusions within red blood cells (RBCs), representing residual nuclear DNA fragments. These inclusions are typically removed by a healthy spleen; their presence often indicates splenic dysfunction or absence.

 

Conditions Associated with Howell–Jolly Bodies

 

The presence of Howell–Jolly bodies is commonly associated with:

 

  • Post-splenectomy: Following surgical removal of the spleen
  • Functional asplenia or hyposplenism: Conditions like sickle cell disease can lead to spleen dysfunction
  • Megaloblastic anemia: Due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
  • Severe hemolytic anemia: Where rapid RBC destruction overwhelms the spleen's filtering capacity
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes: Bone marrow disorders affecting blood cell production

 

Educational Objective:

 

In beta thalassemia major, the peripheral blood smear typically shows hypochromic microcytic red blood cells and target cells, which are best represented by Image 1 and Image 3.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, cough, weight loss, histology of the pathology is as shown below. What is the most likely cytokine involved? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • IFN-γ is crucial in the immune response against intracellular pathogens, including the activation of macrophages and the formation of granulomas, as seen in tuberculosis and other granulomatous diseases. It is produced primarily by T-helper cells (Th1) and is critical for orchestrating the cellular immune response that results in the granuloma formation evident in the provided histology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complement 5a protein: Involved in the inflammatory process, enhancing the immune response by attracting immune cells to sites of infection, but not directly involved in granuloma formation.

 

Option C. Histamine: A mediator in allergic reactions, involved in vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, not typically associated with chronic inflammatory or granulomatous responses.

 

Option D. Prostaglandin: These are lipid compounds that mediate inflammation. Like histamine, they are more often associated with immediate inflammatory responses and pain, rather than chronic inflammation or granuloma formation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Interferon gamma is key in managing intracellular infections and is responsible for the activation of macrophages and other immune cells that culminate in granuloma formation, a central feature in controlling persistent pathogens such as those seen in tuberculosis.

choices.text: β-2 microglobulin
Calcium levels
Serum creatinine

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) β-2 microglobulin

 

β-2 microglobulin is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma.

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

 

  • CRAB criteria for MM
    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl
    • renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min
    • Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dl
    • Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

 

  • Serum Beta 2-microglobulin - It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17 pITP53 sequences and the translocations t (14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium levels: Elevated calcium levels are part of the CRAB criteria and indicate disease activity, but are not as strong a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine: Increased serum creatinine is also part of the CRAB criteria and indicates renal involvement, but it is not the single most powerful predictor.

 

Option D. Protein levels: Protein levels can be elevated due to monoclonal proteins produced by myeloma cells, but again, they are not as powerful a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

choices.text: Vitamin B12 deficiency
Folate deficiency
Pyridoxine deficiency

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the classic causes of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Pernicious anemia is a type of megaloblastic anemia caused by autoimmune gastritis and an inability to produce intrinsic factors, resulting in vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Histologically, there is chronic atrophic gastritis with parietal cell loss, a prominent infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells similar to those seen in erythroid precursors.

 

There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

 

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the a and B subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Folate deficiency: Folate deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia with macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils but is not typically associated with atrophic gastritis.

 

  • Folate deficiency does not usually present with the same gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting) or the autoimmune component seen in pernicious anemia.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine deficiency: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with sideroblastic anemia, not megaloblastic anemia.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Option D. Niacin deficiency: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the "4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency, often due to pernicious anemia, is characterized by macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and atrophic gastritis. This condition involves an autoimmune mechanism that impairs the production and function of intrinsic factor, essential for vitamin B12 absorption.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

 The correct matching is:

 

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a major tumor marker for hepatocellular carcinoma. It's an oncofetal protein that is normally produced during fetal development but can be elevated in certain cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Beta-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is the primary tumor marker for choriocarcinoma. This marker is normally produced during pregnancy but is pathologically elevated in choriocarcinoma, a malignant trophoblastic tumor.
  • Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine) are elevated in pheochromocytoma, which is a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes excessive amounts of these hormones.
  • Calcitonin is the characteristic tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, which arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland that produce this hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor Markers

questions.text: All blood products are separated by Centrifugation except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum albumin

 

Most blood components are separated using centrifugation, which involves different speeds:

 

  1. Low-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates Packed RBCs from platelet-rich plasma (PRP).
  2. High-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates platelets from plasma.
    • Plasma is further processed into Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP).
  3. Cryoprecipitate Preparation:
    • FFP is thawed at 1-6°C, allowing cryoprecipitate to form, which contains Factor VIII, fibrinogen, vWF, and Factor XIII.

 

Thus, platelets, RBCs and cryoprecipitate are all separated using centrifugation.

 

Serum albumin, however, is obtained through a process called fractionation, not centrifugation. This involves:

 

  • Cold ethanol precipitation (Cohn’s method)
  • Ultrafiltration and chromatography techniques

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centrifugation is used to separate RBCs, platelets, and plasma-derived components like cryoprecipitate. Serum albumin, however, is obtained through fractionation, making it the correct answer.

questions.text: When you add calcium and thromboplastin to platelet poor plasma which pathway is assessed? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extrinsic

 

Thromboplastin (Factor III) binds with Factor VII. When calcium is added, it activates extrinsic pathway.

 

 

Activated Prothrombin Time (aPTT) measures the integrity of the intrinsic system (Factors XII, XI, VIII, IX) and common clotting pathways. Calcium and activating substances (kaolin) are added to the plasma-

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic: The intrinsic pathway is assessed using the Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) test, where calcium and an activating substance like kaolin (not thromboplastin) are added to the plasma to measure the activity of Factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII.

 

Option C. Fibrinolysis: Fibrinolysis is the process of breaking down fibrin clots, which is not directly assessed by adding thromboplastin and calcium. It is evaluated by other means, such as measuring fibrin degradation products (FDPs) or D-dimer levels.

 

Option D. Common: While the extrinsic pathway feeds into the common pathway (Factors X, V, II, and I), the specific test described (PT) is primarily assessing the extrinsic pathway, though it also gives some information about the common pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adding calcium and thromboplastin to platelet-poor plasma assesses the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, which is the basis for the Prothrombin Time (PT) test.

questions.text: A physician wanted to perform plasma glucose estimation using the vacutainer shown in the image. Which of the following is the anticoagulant used for this test? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Potassium oxalate

 

  • Potassium oxalate is commonly used in vacutainers for plasma glucose estimation because it acts as both an anticoagulant and it prevents clotting by binding calcium in the blood. We presume that the examiner by mistake showed the blue topped vacutainer in place of the gray one. However let us review that blue-topped vacutainer contains Trisodium citrate while the gray-topped vacutainer contains Potassium oxalate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisodium Citrate: Used primarily as an anticoagulant in blood collection tubes for coagulation studies, not suitable for glucose estimation because it does not prevent glycolysis effectively.

 

Option C. Sodium fluoride: Also a glycolysis inhibitor and commonly used with an anticoagulant (potassium oxalate) in glucose testing..

 

Option D. EDTA: Mainly used as an anticoagulant in hematology tests. While it effectively prevents blood clots, it does not inhibit glycolysis, making it unsuitable for glucose tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate plasma glucose estimation, potassium oxalate and enolase is used because it effectively prevents blood clotting and preserves glucose by inhibiting glycolysis respectively. 

 

Always use a grey-top tube (NaF/KOx) when measuring plasma glucose to prevent post-collection glycolysis and falsely low results.

questions.text: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AB

 

FFP from AB blood group can be given to this patient since the universal plasma donor is AB. AB plasma does not contain antibodies against antigens on RBCs of AB blood group.

 

Here, the question is about fresh frozen plasma transfusion and not about the packed red cells.

 

Had the question been about packed RBCs then in case of emergency packed cell blood transfusion with unknown blood group, O Rh-negative blood (universal donor) is transfused. It is preferred because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens. Hence, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B or anti-D antibodies in the recipient's blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

 

An endo-myocardial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.

 

Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

 

Etiological classification of myocarditis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: MRI can be used to detect myocardial inflammation and scarring, but it is not the gold standard. It is useful for non-invasive assessment but cannot definitively diagnose myocarditis without histological confirmation.

 

Option C. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP): BNP is a biomarker used to assess heart failure but is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Option D. LDH1 to LDH2 ratio: This ratio is sometimes used in the context of myocardial infarction but does not have a role in diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) recognizes? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipids without MHC proteins

 

  • A small population of mature T cells expresses a type of TCR composed of γ and δ polypeptide chains. The γδ TCR recognizes peptides, lipids, and small molecules, without a requirement for display by MHC proteins. γδ T cells tend to aggregate at epithelial surfaces, such as the skin and mucosa of the gastrointestinal and urogenital tracts, suggesting that these cells are sentinels that protect against microbes that try to enter through epithelia
  • The αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are displayed by major histocompatibility complex (MHC. molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). By limiting the specificity of T cells for peptides displayed by cell surface MHC molecules, called MHC restriction, the immune system ensures that T cells see only cell-associated antigens (e.g., those derived from microbes in cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peptides with MHC proteins: This is characteristic of αβ TCRs, not γδ TCRs.

 

Option C. CD20: CD20 is a B cell marker, not a target recognized by T cell receptors.

 

Option D. CD3: CD3 is a signaling molecule associated with the T cell receptor complex but is not a specific target recognized by the TCR itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) are unique in that they can recognize lipids and other molecules without the need for MHC protein presentation, distinguishing them from the more common αβ T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 353

questions.text: Bilateral pedal edema is least likely to be associated with which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic venous insufficiency

 

Bilateral pedal edema is often due to systemic conditions that lead to fluid retention or increased pressure in the veins.

 

Chronic venous insufficiency, typically results from conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is more likely to cause unilateral (one-sided) pedal edema due to localized obstruction of venous return. While chronic venous insufficiency can sometimes cause bilateral edema, it is less common compared to the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic renal failure: Patients with chronic renal failure cannot excrete excess fluid properly, leading to fluid retention and generalized edema, including in both legs.

 

Option C. Congestive heart failure: Heart failure results in increased venous pressure and fluid retention, which typically causes dependent edema, including bilateral pedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic liver disease: Liver disease can lead to hypoalbuminemia and reduced oncotic pressure, causing generalized and bilateral pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency is least likely to be associated with bilateral pedal edema compared to chronic renal failure, congestive heart failure, and chronic liver disease.

 

Edema results from imbalances in:

 

  1. Hydrostatic pressure (↑ in heart failure)
  2. Oncotic pressure (↓ in liver/kidney disease)
  3. Lymphatic drainage
  4. Capillary permeability

 

Summary Table:

choices.text: Lead poisoning
Iron deficiency anemia
Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic alcoholism

 

The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:

 

  • Folate accumulation in the liver
  • Excessive urinary loss
  • Impaired folate metabolism
  • Chronic alcoholics frequently have insufficient dietary intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead poisoning: Lead poisoning typically causes microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. Peripheral smear findings in lead poisoning include basophilic stippling of RBCs, not macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, which contrasts with the macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia generally presents with normocytic or slightly macrocytic RBCs, but not to the extent seen in megaloblastic anemia. Additionally, hyper-segmented neutrophils are not a typical feature of hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrocytic anemia with hyper-segmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, often due to folate deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to impaired folate metabolism and poor dietary intake.

questions.text: Toluidine blue staining is used in the Identification of which of the following cells? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mast Cell

 

Toluidine blue is the special stain for mast cells.

 

Toluidine blue (also known as tolonium chloride) is an acidophilic metachromatic dye that selectively stains acidic tissue components (sulfates, carboxylates, and phosphate radicals). Toluidine blue (TB. has an affinity for nucleic acids, and therefore binds to nuclear material of tissues with a high DNA and RNA content.

 

It also intensely stains some substances leading to a change in color. This effect known as metachromasia.

 

  • Orthochromatic Staining - structures stained blue (Lymphocytes)
  • Metachromatic Staining - structures stained dark purple from polymeric aggregates formed when binding to high concentrations of polyanions (Mast cells)

 

Toluidine blue is often used to identify mast cells by virtue of heparin (which is very polyanionic. found in their secretion granules.

 

 

Application of Toluidine Blue

 

  1. Connective tissue mucins, especially acid mucins. The tissue stains purple to red, while the background is stained blue.
  2. Mast cell granules stain purple in color due to the presence of heparin and histamine.
  3. Amyloid stain blue but under polarized light they give a bright red birefringence.
  4. Endocrine cell granules are stained purple to red.
  5. Sulfatides stain red brown or yellow. Only lipids that are sufficiently acidic to induce a metachromatic shift are stained.
  6. Corynebacterium diphtheria contains granules with polymerized inorganic polyphosphate, which stains red violet color.
  7. Helicobacter stains dark blue against a variably blue background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocyte: Lymphocytes can be stained with toluidine blue, but they show orthochromatic staining (blue), not the metachromasia that is characteristic of mast cells.

 

Option B. Fibroblast: Fibroblasts are not specifically identified by toluidine blue staining.

 

Option C. Macrophage: While macrophages can be stained with various dyes, they do not exhibit the metachromasia seen in mast cells with toluidine blue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue is primarily used to identify mast cells due to their characteristic metachromatic staining caused by the heparin in their granules.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

 

The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

 

 

 

Metaplasia of normal columnar (left) to squamous epithelium (right) in a bronchus

 

  • Another example of metaplasia: BARRETTs esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal development or growth of cells, tissues, or organs. It is characterized by changes in cell size, shape, and organization. Dysplasia can be a precursor to cancer but does not describe the replacement of one cell type by another.

 

Option B. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy is the increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the tissue or organ. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Option C. Atrophy: Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of cells, tissues, or organs, often due to decreased use, insufficient nutrition, or aging. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis, also known as the Chinese liver fluke, is a parasitic worm that infects the bile ducts of the liver. Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis is a well-known risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a type of cancer that occurs in the bile ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular cancer: This is commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B and C infections, cirrhosis, and aflatoxin exposure, not typically with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option C. Gastric cancer: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, dietary factors, and genetic predisposition, not with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option D. Urinary bladder cancer: Often linked to smoking, occupational exposures, and Schistosoma haematobium infection (another type of parasitic worm), not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Humans acquire the infection by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing the metacercariae (infective stage).

 

Chronic infection leads to:

 

  • Inflammation
  • Hyperplasia of the biliary epithelium
  • Fibrosis
  • Malignant transformation → Cholangiocarcinoma

choices.text: Factor V Leiden mutation
Protein C deficiency
Antithrombin III deficiency
G20210A prothrombin gene mutation

questions.text: What is the most common genetic factor responsible for hypercoagulability? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation (Activated protein C resistance) is the most common inherited disorder that causes hypercoagulability.

 

The prothrombin G20210A mutation is the second most common inherited risk factor for thrombosis and leads to increased levels of prothrombin which demonstrates a higher risk for arterial and venous thrombotic events.

 

Protein C & S deficiency, Antithrombin III deficiency, Hyperhomocysteinemia, Elevated factor VIII (FVIII) are other causes of hypercoagulability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Protein C deficiency: Protein C deficiency is a rarer inherited condition that also increases the risk of venous thromboembolism due to impaired inactivation of Factors Va and VIIIa. However, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation.

 

Option C. Antithrombin III deficiency: This is another inherited disorder leading to hypercoagulability. Antithrombin III normally inhibits thrombin and other clotting factors, and its deficiency increases the risk of thrombosis. Again, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation.

 

Option D. G20210A prothrombin gene mutation: This mutation is the second most common inherited risk factor for thrombosis. It leads to increased levels of prothrombin, which is associated with a higher risk for both arterial and venous thrombotic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability, primarily due to resistance to Activated Protein C.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Neurosecretory bodies except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adrenal cortical tumor

 

Neurosecretory bodies are not seen in adrenal cortical tumors.

 

Adrenocortical neoplasms produce aldosterone. Primary hyperaldosteronism due to a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma is Conn syndrome.

 

Microscopically, aldosterone-producing adenomas show spironolactone bodies which are eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions found after treatment with spironolactone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C-cells, which are neuroendocrine cells. These cells secrete calcitonin and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Option B. Pituitary adenoma: Pituitary adenomas are tumors of the pituitary gland, many of which are neuroendocrine in nature. They can produce hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone, or ACTH, and neurosecretory granules can be found in these tumors.

 

Option C. Paraganglioma: Paragangliomas are tumors that arise from paraganglia, which are collections of neuroendocrine cells. These cells are closely related to the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurosecretory bodies are associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but not with adrenal cortical tumors, which originate from the adrenal cortex and are involved in steroid hormone production.

 

Tumors associated with neurosecretory granules

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Acute myeloid leukemia
Chronic myelogenous leukemia

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

 

The peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

The blood contains large numbers of small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells are usually disrupted in the process of making smears, producing so-called smudge cells. Lymphocytes are of same size and configuration with a uniform appearance called as "convent-girl" appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): The peripheral smear in ALL typically shows a high number of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. There would be an absence of smudge cells, which are characteristic of CLL.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML is characterized by the presence of myeloblasts in the peripheral blood smear. These cells are larger, have more cytoplasm, and may contain Auer rods. Again, smudge cells are not a feature of AML.

 

Option D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): The peripheral smear in CML shows a full spectrum of myeloid cells, from myeloblasts to mature neutrophils, often with an increase in basophils and eosinophils. Smudge cells are not a characteristic finding in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease

 

Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis seen in Kimmelstiel Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

 

These lesions are specific for type 1 diabetes (juvenile onset diabetes) or islet cell antibody-positive diabetes mellitus.

 

The pathologic changes consist of one or more nodules in a few or many glomeruli. Nodule is an ovoid or spherical, laminated, hyaline, acellular mass located within a lobule of the glomerulus.

 

The nodules are surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillary loops which may have normal or thickened GBM. The nodules are PAS-positive and contain lipid and fibrin. These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman's capsules (“capsular drops”).

 

 

As the nodular lesions enlarge, they compress the glomerular capillaries and obliterate the glomerular tuft. As a result of glomerular and arteriolar involvement, renal ischemia occurs leading to tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and grossly small, contracted kidney.

 

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

 

Diabetic nephropathy encompasses 4 types of renal lesions in diabetes mellitus:

 

1. Diabetic glomerulosclerosis (Diffuse/ Nodular)

 

  1. Diffuse lesions are characterized by diffuse involvement of the glomeruli showing thickening of the GBM and diffuse increase in the mesangial matrix with mild proliferation of mesangial cells and exudative lesions (fibrin caps and capsular drops)
  2. Nodular lesion (Kimmelstiel-Wilson Lesion) is characterized by one or more hyaline nodules within the lobules of glomeruli, surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillaries with thickened walls.

 

 

2.  Vascular lesions – Hyaline arterioslerosis

Morphology

 

 

3. Diabetic pyelonephritis – Papillary necrosis / Necrotizing papillitis

 

4. Tubular lesions (Armanni-Ebstein lesions).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal amyloidosis: Amyloidosis presents with amyloid deposits, typically visualized using Congo red stain, which is different from the PAS-positive nodules seen in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli and does not present with the diffuse nodular glomerulosclerosis observed in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option D. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis involves immune complex deposition, which leads to a different set of histological changes, including "wire loop" lesions, which are not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, a specific form of diabetic nephropathy, is characterized by PAS-positive nodules within the glomeruli, often associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 2206

choices.text: Dystrophic with increased serum calcium
Metastatic with increased serum calcium
Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

 

Atheromatous plaques show dystrophic calcification in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

 

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

 

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type -

 

Calcification in dead tissue –

 

  1. Caseous necrosis in tuberculosis is the most common site for dystrophic calcification.
  2. Liquefaction necrosis in chronic abscesses may get calcified.
  3. Fat necrosis following acute pancreatitis or traumatic fat necrosis in the breast results in deposition of calcium soaps.
  4. Gamma-Gandy bodies in chronic venous congestion (CVC. of the spleen is characterized by calcific deposits admixed with hemosiderin on fibrous tissue.
  5. Infarcts may sometimes undergo dystrophic calcification.
  6. Thrombi, especially in the veins, may produce phleboliths.
  7. Hematomas in the vicinity of bones may undergo dystrophic calcification.
  8. Dead parasites like in hydatid cyst, Schistosoma eggs, and cysticercosis are some of the examples showing dystrophic calcification.
  9. Calcification in breast cancer detected by mammography.
  10. Congenital toxoplasmosis involving the central nervous system visualized by calcification in the infant brain.

 

Calcification in degenerated tissues

 

  1. Dense old scars may undergo hyaline degeneration and subsequent calcification.
  2. Atheromatous in the aorta and coronaries frequently undergo calcification.
  3. Mönckeberg’s sclerosis shows calcification in the tunica media of muscular arteries in elderly people
  4. Stroma of tumors such as uterine fibroids, breast cancer, thyroid adenoma, goitre etc. show calcification.
  5. Some tumors show characteristic spherules of calcification called psammoma bodies or calcospherites such as in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary and papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
  6. Cysts which have been present for a long time may show calcification of their walls e.g. epidermal and pilar cysts.
  7. Calcinosis cutis is a condition of unknown cause in which there are irregular nodular deposits of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  8. Senile degenerative changes may be accompanied by dystrophic calcification such as in costal cartilages, tracheal or bronchial cartilages, and pineal gland in the brain etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dystrophic with increased serum calcium: Dystrophic calcification typically occurs in the setting of normal serum calcium levels. While hypercalcemia can exacerbate dystrophic calcification, it is not a defining feature.

 

Option B. Metastatic with increased serum calcium: Metastatic calcification occurs when calcium salts are deposited in normal tissues as a result of hypercalcemia. This form of calcification is not associated with tissue injury or necrosis and typically affects tissues like the lungs, stomach, kidneys, and blood vessels under conditions of high serum calcium. It does not apply to the situation described, where calcification is occurring in damaged tissue with normal calcium levels.

 

Option D. Metastatic with normal serum calcium: This option is incorrect because metastatic calcification is always associated with hypercalcemia, not normal serum calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 83

choices.text: Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 (PECAM-1)

questions.text: Which of the following molecules are involved in helping the leukocytes to roll over the endothelial cells in the vessels? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E-selectin

 

E-selectins are involved in rolling of leucocytes over endothelial cells.

 

Cellular Changes during Inflammation

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cadherins: These are involved in cell-cell adhesion in various tissues but are not specifically involved in the rolling of leukocytes during inflammation.

 

Option B. PECAM-1 (Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1): PECAM-1 is primarily involved in the process of diapedesis, where leukocytes transmigrate across the endothelium.

 

Option D. CD11a: This is an integrin (part of the LFA-1 complex) involved in the firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium, not in the rolling process.

 

Educational Objective:


E-selectin is critical for the rolling of leukocytes along the endothelial cells during the early stages of the inflammatory response.
